results.title: Stalin: the power of fear
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson
results.brief_description: Examines the price of Stalinism in the aftermath of World War II: possibly between forty and eighty million lives lost in wars, starvation, execution, and unnecessary deaths. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson

results.title: Stalin: man and image
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson
results.brief_description: A documentary examining the image Stalin created by exploring the man, his rise to power and his place in history. Historical perspective is provided by use of classic film footage showing the 1917 Russian Revolution, Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Stalag 17
results.brief_description: Set in a German prisoner-of-war camp, “Stalag 17” is about a group of American sergeants confined to one barrack, trying to survive wartime restrictions and spartan conditions. Amid the soldiers is one man, Sefton, a canny operator and racketeer who has amassed a case of contraband that enables him to bribe favours, providing him with more comfortable surrounds. When a meticulously planned escape is expertly foiled, the men suspect a traitor within the ranks; soon all suspicions turn to Sefton, whose compassion has been battered out of him after years as a POW, but could he be a Nazi collaborator? Effectively utilising the confines of the barrack as an incendiary setting for pent up frustrations, Wilder successfully explores the mob mentality in a compelling manner; less compelling (at least dramatically) are the humorous moments operating as light relief which stagnate the drama, diluting the well crafted tension. “Stalag 17” was one of the first films to convey war with humour - a definite precursor to “MASH”, “Catch-22” and the campy outlandishness of “Hogan’s Heroes”. William Holden won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the embittered Sefton - a role he apparently reluctantly played. Cast includes Don Taylor, Otto Preminger, Robert Strauss, Harvey Lembeck, Peter Graves, Richard Erdman, Sig Rumann and Neville Brand.

results.title: Staking a claim
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Lois Bianchi, Simon Berthon, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
A new continent is discovered and the shape of the world is changed yet again. To begin with, the discovery of America, was merely a step in finding a new route to the east. However with Cortes and his expeditions inland, the Europeans discovered a new civilisation and new riches in the form of gold. The Spanish, Portuguese, English and French exploited this wealth and eventually settled the continent. Meanwhile the Dutch established their empire in the east, and discovered Australia. Mapmaking took a giant step forward with the discovery of longitude.

results.title: Stairway to heaven
results.brief_description: This film deals with the study of astronomy from the time of the early Egyptians and Greeks, through the Middle Ages, when Galileo’s asertion that the earth moved revolutionised science, until the present day. The discovery of the telescope, and its development to the precision instrument it is today, is dealt with in detail.

results.brief_description: Artists and master craftsmen are shown designing and constructing stained-glass windows and lampshades. Explores both traditional and contemporary examples of this art form.

results.title: Stained glass at Fairford
results.brief_description: St Mary’s Church, Fairford, Gloucestershire is famous for its medieval stained glass windows, illustrating the Bible Story from the Garden of Eden to the Day of Judgment. This film provides a detailed study of the windows, which are notable for their wide range of characterisation and facial expression. The final sections, dealing with the Day of Judgment and the descent into Hell, conjure up a nightmare world reminiscent of Bosch. John Betjeman is the commentator and Robert Donat reads relevant passages from the authorised version of the Bible.

results.title: Stained glass
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the craft of making stained glass. Craftsmen are seen at work preparing the design for a stained glass window; drawing the cartoon and tracing the outlines on glass; finally leading, soldering and cementing the pieces into place in the finished window.

results.title: Staggered
results.creator_credit: Philippa Braithwaite, Big Deal Picures and Martin Clunes
results.brief_description: Neil Price (Clunes), a children’s toy salesman, is preparing to marry an upper crust girl named Hilary, despite the disapproval of her snobbish mother. Three days before the nuptials, on the night of his stag party, Neil has his drink spiked by best friend Gary, and is left stranded naked on a remote Scottish island. Neil has to somehow make his way back to London for his wedding, aided by the kindness of strangers. Naturally Neil falls into all manner of strife en route - he’s arrested, has an arm broken, survives an armed robbery, and steals several cars. Meanwhile in Neil’s mysterious absence, Gary and Hilary’s mother go to work on her so that she will marry Gary instead of Neil on her wedding day. This romantic comedy places the rubbery-faced Clunes (from TV’s Men behaving badly) in all kind of sticky situations as well as pairing him opposite the comely Carmen (Anna Chancellor), who assists Neil in his quest (and provides an alternate love interest). The film features an array of exaggerated types (repressed sexual deviants, wry octogenarians, duplicitous friends) to draw laughs as it places Neil in increasingly farcical scenarios. Cast includes Michael Praed, Michele Winstanley, Kate Byers, Sarah Winman, David Kossoff and Helena McCarthy.

results.title: Stagestruck 3
results.creator_credit: Spellcaster Productions, TLC Films and Bob Harvey
results.brief_description: A compilation of 5 separate episodes, this is the final of a series of three videos on everything you would like to know about theatre production, and in particular, amateur theatre. Presented by Christina Barryk, aspects covered in this volume include: Stage manager’s tools of the trade, arranging of actors’ moves on stage, dress rehearsal hints and tips; Makeup techniques; Prop designing, casting and moulding; Technical rehearsal; Actors’ improvisation workshops, role-casting/role-playing, reality on stage; Costume design and making of costume, transforming actor into character. Final episode celebrates amateur dramatics, including the actors and the behind scenes technical crew. Also includes personal anecdotes interspersed thoughout the program.
